In addition to its relevance to the story of Jacob, the concept of mortality salience has been the subject of extensive research in the field of psychology. Studies have shown that when individuals are reminded of their own mortality, they may experience a range of psychological and behavioral effects.

For example, mortality salience has been shown to increase the appeal of individuals' cultural worldviews and belief systems, as well as their desire to affiliate with like-minded others. This effect, known as "worldview defense," suggests that the awareness of one's own mortality may motivate individuals to seek a sense of security and belonging within their social groups.

Mortality salience has also been shown to increase prosocial behaviors, such as generosity, forgiveness, and altruism, as individuals seek to leave a positive impact on the world before they die.

Overall, the concept of mortality salience highlights the importance of recognizing the finite nature of our lives and the potential impact this can have on our thoughts, feelings, and actions. By embracing this awareness, individuals may be inspired to live more intentionally and purposefully, striving to make the most of their time on earth and leaving a meaningful legacy for future generations.
